    Head 42 -

    Mr Lee Choon Eng (Queenstown): Speaker, Sir, I rise to move,

    That the sum to be allotted for Head 42 be reduced by $36,240 in respect of subhead 8 therein.

    According to this item, we are asked to provide $36,240 for fees for an adviser on land titles and, according to the explanation in the footnote, I see he is required to draft rules and regulations and to prepare a textbook explaining the law and practice of the Land Titles Ordinance (No. 21 of 1956). Sir, it is very surprising that there are no experts within the Ministry to draft rules or regulations and to prepare textbooks regarding the Land Titles Ordinance. In the Ministry, I do find that we have one Commissioner of Lands, one Deputy Commissioner of Lands, one Registrar of Titles and one Examiner of Titles. We have four senior officers who are well conversant with land titles and so forth, and yet they are not in a position to prepare a Land Titles Ordinance or to draft rules and regulations. I cannot see why, Sir. What are they for? We employ senior officers for the purpose of running that Ministry. All of them have qualifications on land titles and so forth, yet they cannot prepare these draft rules and regulations.

Column: 3229



    If my memory serves me right, Sir, I think sometime last year or so we sent our former Commissioner of Lands, who is now, I understand, the Permanent Secretary, to Australia to study this question of land titles. He is back with us. What has he done and why cannot he prepare the draft rules or regulations? Is it necessary that we should now appoint a special adviser to prepare them at a cost to Government and the public of $36,240? Will this not be a waste of funds? If the senior officers in the Ministry cannot prepare them, they are not fit to remain in office. I am rather surprised that the Minister is not aware whether officers in it can or cannot prepare such rules and regulations in respect of land titles.

    The Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing (Inche Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat): Mr Speaker, Sir, it is not the Minister who is not aware of something happening in his Ministry, I think it is the hon. Member for Queenstown who is not aware.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: I cannot be.

    Inche Abdul Hamid: We still do not have a Registrar of Titles although we have advertised for the post; there have been interviews by the Public Service Commission - four times, I think - yet we are still without a Registrar of Titles.

    These rules and regulations with regard to land titles, Sir, are for a new system of land tenure. We are using this system in Singapore for the first time and I am afraid that the officers in my Ministry do not have the expert knowledge which is required for such a system.

    I do not think I have anything further to say.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Minister tell us what experience our former Commissioner of Lands gained whilst he was in Australia to learn this question of land titles? He was sent there for a particular purpose - to learn the Ordinance or to learn something about land titles. He is back, and I am sure the Minister cannot say that he does not have a Commissioner of

Column: 3230

Lands or that he has no one to whom to give this appointment. He went to Australia at our expense and what has the Ministry or the Singapore Government benefited? We sent him there to learn all about the subject yet he is not in a position to prepare draft rules and regulations.

    Inche Abdul Hamid: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Permanent Secretary was sent to Australia sometime back to study the new system of land titles. He is partly responsible for the Land Titles Ordinance which was passed in 1956.

    Mr R. C. H. Lim (Nominated): Mr Speaker, Sir, to a layman it may seem easy to formulate rules for the proposed title to land under the intended registration system but to those who know, as I do, it is a difficult job. It needs expert advice, otherwise when the regulations are made, they may either not be applicable or, if they do, may lead to misunderstandings under the proposed Ordinance.

    Question on the amendment put, and negatived.

    Question proposed,

    "That the sum of $276,690 for Head 42 stand part of the Schedule."

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Speaker, Sir, in 1955 the Government set up a Working Committee to investigate and report on the question of land clearance and resettlement. This report was tabled in this Assembly in 1956 and adopted. It is now more than 1½ years but what has the Government done to the recommendations contained in that report? The only scheme so far realised, as far as I am aware, is in the resettlement of the slum areas of Queenstown and Henderson Road.

    Apart from these two areas, what has the Government done? Can the Minister tell this House how many other areas he has in mind to carry out this resettlement scheme? And another most important question is, if he has any other area in mind, will these future areas be concentrated on a communal basis?

Column: 3231



    If my memory is correct, Sir, when the Minister stood for election in 1955 he stood under the Alliance banner, with the support, may I say, of the Labour Front. He approached the Labour Front for support and he was elected. When he stood for election, one of his platforms was, 'If I am elected, I will strive for the betterment of the attap dwellers. I will do all I can for the attap dwellers -'

    Inche Abdul Hamid: I never said so.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Well, that is one of his platforms and that of the Labour Front as well. At that time I was in the Labour Front and I know what its platform was. Sir, may I say that this is one of those election pledges that a candidate puts to the public just as a vote-catching stunt but is never fulfilled. A promise was made during the last elections but its fulfilment has yet to come.

10.15 a.m.

    The Hon. Member is now a Minister of the Labour Front Coalition Government today, and it so happens that he has been made Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing, which gives him all the power to do what he can for the attap dwellers. What has he done, Sir, during these 2½ years in office? As for as I can see, there are still plenty of slum areas in the Colony. What has he done after all his promises to the electors in his division, Ulu Bedok, and to those in the Colony in general? He has practically done nothing at all. I do not know how he will face his electorate when he goes back to the country next year. I would like to see how he tells them when he goes back.

    My next point, Sir, is on the question of a housing authority. This subject has been brought up in this Assembly time and time again but do we have a housing authority yet? There is none. May I refresh the Minister, Sir, that when he assumed office he said that he would set up a housing authority. Has he forgotten that? He said that within a very short time he would certainly set up one. May I refresh his

Column: 3232

memory by reading from Volume 1, No. 1, of the Official Report for 22nd April, 1955, column 40? When he assumed office, he said:

    "In addition, it is proposed to tackle the housing problem more vigorously and efficiently by setting up a statutory Housing Authority, solely responsible to Government, to replace the present Singapore Improvement Trust. It is hoped that such a Housing Authority would be able in a comparatively short time to bridge the increasing gap between public housing programmes and the needs of the people."

    Sir, he says "a comparatively short time". May I ask the Minister, Sir, how short is a "short time", or it may be how long? I do not know what he means by it. It may mean the time from the day he assumed office until the day he is no more in it. That would be from three-and-a-half to four years; would that be a "short time"? May I also remind the Minister, Sir, that life is also short.

    Sir, I would like to refer to my question on 16th October, 1957, on the progress of the establishment of this housing authority. I will refresh his memory by reading what he said (column 2656):

    "I am not quite sure whether the hon. Member wants a report or a statement on the question of the progress of the establishment of a Housing Authority. He has asked me to make a statement. A statement can be in one sentence or in twenty sentences. I have made my statement in one sentence."

    He made his statement very, very short in - one sentence - and I think that is what he meant by a "short time". In his reply, I may say - if I may be allowed to continue on this subject - he said, "there is no delay in the establishment of a Housing Authority." I will read again, from column 2656:

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Is the Minister aware of the concern of the public in the long delay in setting up this Housing Authority?

    Inche Abdul Hamid: There is no delay, Sir."

    Now, Sir, he has been two-and-a-half years in office and he has promised this House that he will, "in a comparatively short time", set up a housing authority. Two-and-a-half years is not enough for the Government to set it up! Every time this question is brought up in this

Column: 3233

House, the reply is that it is still under consideration and that 'we will submit a report very soon, or "in due course," which is the normal term of the Government'. How long more will this delay be? Is it going to be until he leaves the Ministry or until he is no more in office?

    Now as long as this Housing Authority is not established, there will be no proper authority to take over the S.I.T. The Minister himself realises that the housing authority is most essential to take over from the S.I.T., as he stated on 22nd April, 1955, column 40 of the Official Report. Yet, after two-and-a-half years we do not have a housing authority to take over. And what is the result? - there are still thousands and thousands of outstanding applications for S.I.T. accommodation. They are still waiting and waiting. Is it the function of the S.I.T. to keep people in suspense, waiting and waiting for accommodation? How long will it take? May I say that it is a real shame for the Minister to say, in reply to a question of mine sometime this year, that so far in 1957 not a single house has been allotted to the public. What a shame! And what a government which states that it will provide houses and so forth and yet has not one single house or one single flat allotted to the public this year.

    May I remind the Government or the Labour Front, Sir, that on its posters during Election time, it was stated in Chinese, "Clothing, food and housing: If elected, if we come into power, we will provide the public with these three essentials. Number one is clothing; we will provide the public with clothing. Next, we will provide the public with food; and next, we will provide the public with housing." This is the poster put up by the Labour Front at that time. I was lucky that I did not use these Labour Front posters for my election purposes - I had my own posters - and I am therefore not responsible or a party to that statement. Housing is of the most important platforms of the Government or Labour Front, yet after all these years it cannot find a house for the public!

Column: 3234



    What is this, Sir? Is this what the Government is trying to do, to neglect its duty and delay and delay? When are we going to have houses? When do we expect to have the slum areas cleared? I would like to ask the Minister: when can he make a final decision on this housing authority? I am quite sure his reply again will be, 'Within a very short time'. But I would like a definite and a specific 'short time' - is it to be a matter of a day, a week, a month or in another l½ years when he may be no more in office!

    Sir, the next point I would like to refer to is the decision made by the S.I.T. on citizenship and eligibility for houses, which is now being referred to the Government. The Board of the S.I.T. has decided that only Singapore Citizens can apply for accommodation and that no one else can. Prior to this decision, aliens who have been here 10 years and more could apply. What is the S.I.T. going to do with the applications now in its hands from aliens? The reply may be that since they are aliens, they are not considered to be local people, and will not be provided with S.I.T. accommodation.

    May I remind the House that I asked a question: what would be the fate of those who wanted to become citizens but could not get themselves registered by 31st January, 1958? I believe my question was ruled out as being hypothetical and I could not press the matter further. Now is it the fault of these aliens? Is it that they do not want to become citizens? It is not their fault. They are anxious to become citizens of Singapore but just because of the rush, the crowds and the long queues lined up at all the registration centres they cannot have a chance to get themselves registered in time. Is the S.I.T. going to deprive them of a house? Is it going to scrap all applications from these aliens, applications submitted long ago? Some might have submitted their applications five years ago, or even 10 years ago. Yet today the S.I.T. has decided, and the Government may decide, that they will be removed from the register or waiting list. Is it fair, Sir, that after

Column: 3235

waiting in suspense for five to ten years, and with no fault of not wanting to become Singapore citizens, they will have to be chucked out of the register?

    I hope that the Government will take note of all these points and I would like to hear what the Minister has to say in reply.

    Mr Lim Koon Teck (Paya Lebar): Mr Speaker, Sir, I endorse the remarks of the hon. Member for Queenstown, particularly those concerning the housing authority. The delay in the establishment of this housing authority, up to the closing stages of the life of the present Government, has thrown the whole housing programme, particularly those of private builders, completely out of gear. With no central authority to deal with plans, and with plans having to be submitted in seven copies to different bodies - the Singapore Improvement Trust, the City Council or the Rural Board, the Health Department and others - and the insistence that everything must be cleared before being passed from one body to another, plans have taken over a year to be approved. Sometimes even after a year, plans are sent back and the architects who sent them in are asked to submit new ones, because new ideas have come up about the siting of roads and their standards. This has caused such delay that, instead of building the 3,000 houses which I anticipated two companies in Singapore could have done, they have only completed about 1,000.

    Sir, unfortunately this delay has now caused the collapse of all private development because of the money tightness and the disinflationery squeeze. No loans can now be obtained from the building societies. Therefore, you are not going to get any more houses built by the public investing people.

    Sir, I have always advocated that housing should be the work not only of Government, but private developers as well, private developers to cater for those who earn more than $400 or $500 a month - particularly senior Government

Column: 3236

servants who are about to retire, who can buy their own houses and when the time for retirement comes have a house of their own - and the S.I.T. to house people with smaller incomes who are unable to buy the houses, and of course some unfortunate people who always have to be helped by subsidy from Government. But all this now, Sir, has been thrown completely out of gear and I do urge Government to bring this housing authority into being as soon as possible, so that we can get on with the work.

    Another very important aspect of this housing authority is in the provision of factory sites, as we are now striving for secondary or light industries. If we are to encourage the establishment of industries, we must not insist on standards of building which make it impossible for a small man with a capital of, say $10,000 to $20,000, to start a factory. You have to be realistic. You have to provide sites quickly and allow them to put up their own buildings as cheaply as possible consistent with safety. I have seen plans being refused because the standards of building are not high enough. Well, in the past, nearly 100 years in Singapore, not a single factory has collapsed on the workers.

    It is important that we must get plans for factories for light industries approved within three months at the latest; not when you sent it in, it is sent back again and the reason it is asked to be withdrawn is because it does not conform to the requirements of the Master Plan. They put it very nicely of course; they say, 'Will you do this and that?' But all that takes time.

    I am sure if Government wants to help, it can be done. And it must be done, otherwise we will be burdened with more and more unemployment.

10.30 a.m.

    Mr William Tan (Tiong Bahru): Mr Speaker, Sir, I strongly endorse the remarks made by my colleague, the hon. Member for Paya Lebar, on the establishment of a Housing Authority in Singapore. We have allotted large sums of money to the Singapore Improvement

Column: 3237

Trust and what has been done with all of it? No houses have been built and, as the Member for Queenstown has said, there is a long waiting list of applicants.

    I can inform the Hon. the Minister for Housing that at the moment, if he were to pay a visit to the office of the Planning Section of the S.I.T., he will find piles and piles of plans, development plans, lying idle there. Those plans have been there for months and months, yet no action has been taken. Why? The Planning Section was formerly run by four officers but now I understand that one of the officers is on leave, one has been boarded out and the third transferred to be Acting Chairman of the S.I.T. (because the Chairman of the S.I.T. has been transferred to be adviser to the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing). Why cannot more officials be put in the Department in view of the fact that those development plans are essential for this country? People want to invest money in this country. They submit their plans but what has the S.I.T. done? It has done no work! It is really a shame.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy (Telok Ayer): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like just to comment on the speech made by the hon. Member for Queenstown regarding citizenship registration. I understand that 500,000 application forms have been given out by the Department concerned. I read in the Press this morning that 166,000 people have been registered by now. I think it is high time the Department looks into the matter very carefully - how many persons it expects will be registered, how many have registered and what is the balance of expected registrations, and to appoint more registration teams. Surely Government can appoint more teams because people are finding difficulty. When they ask for a registration team, they are given dates further and further off and the people are not sure that they can be registered within the period. I agree that the registration period should never be extended but the opportunity should be taken of having more teams so that people who want to get registered can be satisfied.

Column: 3238



    The Minister for Education (Mr Chew Swee Kee): Mr Speaker, Sir, it is really gratifying to note that all Members of the Opposition support and endorse the housing authority which is one of the principles of the Labour Front and not of the Opposition. I am glad to note that they endorse something which they never even thought of when they stood for election.

    Mr Lim Koon Teck: In reply to that, the housing authority was thought of and was planned long before the Front came into being.

    Inche Abdul Hamid: Sir, it is also very fine to see that the Liberal-Socialists have now got new friends.

    With regard to the report of the Working Party on land clearance in 1956. I think we have done a lot, but in so far as this Government is concerned, we do first things first, and amongst the things that we have done was the resettlement of the squatters in Queenstown and other parts of the city from areas primarily required for Singapore Improvement Trust schemes. I think we have done a wonderful job, although the Opposition does not think so.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Self-praise!

    Inche Abdul Hamid: There are at the moment 70 areas for resettlement under investigation which will comprise almost 2,600 farm lots.

    With regard to the allegation by the Member for Queenstown that I have made promises during my election campaign to attap dwellers and so on, may I remind the Member that I made no such promises? All I did say was that I would do my very best for the people of Singapore, irrespective of whether they lived in Ulu Bedok or Queenstown.

    On the question of the housing authority, Members of the Opposition seem to think that you can put up a housing authority within a matter of months, and even within a matter of weeks or days. Well, Sir, the legislation for a housing authority is a very complicated one. I know we have taken two and a half years but I did promise at an earlier sitting

Column: 3239

of this Assembly that a Bill for the housing authority would be introduced at the very first opportunity during the next session of the Assembly. I hope to have it introduced for its First Reading at its very first sitting.

    On the allegation that the S.I.T. has been sleeping and has not been building any house, may I remind Members that, at the time I replied to questions in this Assembly to the effect that no housing units had been completed or allocated between August 1956 and April 1957, there were no less than 4,000 houses under construction? By the end of 1958, most of these houses will have been completed - and probably allocated as well.

    There is the other allegation, about delay in passing plans. Here again, Sir, I have explained to the House that the S.I.T. is not the only authority responsible for passing plans. For instance, you have also the City Council, and I , as Minister, cannot in any way interfere with the workings of the City Council. Similarly, you have the Rural Board, probably the Ministry of Health and other departments, whose "chops" you must have on the plans before you can proceed with the building.

    Mr William Tan: Do something about it!

    Inche Abdul Hamid: But if I may say this, if there are any members of the public who feel that they have been let down very badly by the Planning Department of the S.I.T., I shall be only too glad to be of any assistance to them, particularly, I think, to the Member for Paya Lebar.

    Mr Lim Cher Kheng (Changi): Mr Speaker, I think this House will agree that the Hon. the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing has failed to answer the allegation raised by the hon. Member for Tiong Bahru about shortage of staff in the Planning Department of the Singapore Improvement Trust. Of course we accept that it is quite a complicated matter for a plan to pass through the Rural Board, the

Column: 3240

City Council and other bodies, but I think it is generally known that the S.I.T. is the main body causing all the delay in passing plans.

    My second point is that this House has yet to be informed by the Minister when he can promise it that the housing authority can be set up to take over the S.I.T.

    I wish to add my last point for the Government to consider. Since under the Master Plan, satellite towns are going to be set up, I wonder why Government insists on building multi-storeyed houses to house what I should say are middle class people able to pay at least $30 per flat. But how about those who live in cubicles and pay from $10 to $20 for a single room? Does the Government ever consider building more low-cost housing to house those who are really poor? These people cannot afford to pay the lowest rent charged by the S.I.T., i.e. $30. I suggest that there are many vacant pieces of land in the rural areas or outskirts of the city on which we can build cheap houses (especially as we have an expert on houses with us - I mean the hon. Member for Paya Lebar, Mr Lim Koon Teck, who can build low-cost houses) and charge a very low rent. This will enable the poor to enjoy the fresh air and sunshine as others do.

    I wonder whether the S.I.T. in its planning has studied the surveys made by the Social Welfare Department of the average income of the people in Singapore, and considered how many people can afford to pay the rent it charges. Many people cannot pay the rent by themselves and are forced to invite relatives or friends to share their flats, which is against the regulations, and they are asked to quit. But does the S.I.T. not know that these people would like to have the whole flat to themselves as much as do those who can afford to pay? As they cannot afford to pay the rent themselves, they therefore have to invite relatives, friends or even strangers to share their flats. Yet the S.I.T. rules that this is against regulations. In order, therefore, to save all the trouble to be to visit the Courts, I wish and strongly suggest that Government will follow the summoned in and summoned out, and

Column: 3241

principle of setting up satellite towns and build many, many more low-cost houses in them for the poor.

    Mr William Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, is it not the duty of the Hon. the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing to pay a visit to the Planning Section of the Singapore Improvement Trust? He will find there the cause of the delay in the approval of the development plans. In that small office, all around, even in the corners, he will find piles and piles of plans, plans which have lain idle for months and months.

    We want prosperity in Singapore. If you have those plans passed, we will create it. They are development plans; they are essential. They will create employment for our people. They will lead to the building of more factories. Why then are there delays?

    As the Minister responsible, it is his duty to pay a visit to this office. I understand that the department is understaffed. Before, its work was done by four officers, as I said earlier in my speech, but it is now being run by only one officer. Why should there be delay? It is his duty to check it up.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Speaker, I want to make a few comments in reply to the Minister. I think he said that he has 70 areas comprising about 2,600 farm plots for clearance and resettlement. I am not clear whether he has already cleared these 70 areas, or that there are 70 areas in all in the Colony to be cleared. If it is 70 areas to be cleared, I would like the Minister to tell us how many has he cleared so far.

10.45 a.m.

    My next point is that he said he made no promise during his election campaign to provide better conditions of living for attap dwellers. May I call it a tradition, Sir, for promises always to be made by candidates during election time, but when they get into power, they forget the promises? So I will not blame him for not being aware now or not being able to remember having made such a promise. As a member of the public who was at his election rallies, I think I can remember better.

Column: 3242



    The third point is on the housing authority. He said that at the first opportunity he would report to this Assembly on its establishment. I do hope sincerely, Sir, that the next time we sit here, he will place legislation for a housing authority before this House, and that after the next sitting we will in fact have a housing authority to take over the S.I.T.

    My fourth point is that he said I accused him or the Government of not having built any houses.
